Award.AwardTitle: Science of Pattern Coating onto Heterogeneous Surfaces Using a Hybrid Manufacturing Process

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scaling the fabrication of thin films from the laboratory to manufacturing floor has been a difficult and time-consuming process. This is due in part to a lack of understanding important factors associated with the scalability of materials, in addition to the lack of advanced manufacturing approaches to fabricate thin films with desired properties, quality and/or functionality, at low cost and/or high speed. This is due, in part, to the difference in scale and approach between the discovery and development of new functional thin film materials, in the lab, and the use of scaled manufacturing techniques. Multilayer thin film devices are spread across many existing and emerging technological areas, including organic solar cells, displays, sensors, solid-state lighting, ubiquitous smart devices, and other applications. Thin organic films and film multilayers will play an increasingly important role in the formation of new products that demand high performance but low-cost. These thin films are typically formed from liquid films deposited onto and wetting mechanical supports or often flexible plastic substrates. In this research, the mechanisms that limit the scaling of emerging devices due to the interactions of fluids coated on dissimilar surfaces are elucidated and paths leading to manufacturability developed. This work supports the need for decreasing manufacturing costs and increasing the manufacturing rate of multilayer thin films. The grant enables the participation of undergraduates, principally from underrepresented groups, into the research activities.

The objective of this study is to investigate the influence of material properties and processing conditions on the ability to coat low viscosity electrode polymer fluids onto flexible substrates, to produce complex multilayer heterogeneous patterns, which will advance manufacturing knowledge for fabricating 3D thin film structures used in flexible electronics. The diverse range of defects that can be traced back to interfacial phenomena substantiates the importance of understanding the process-structure relationship of patterned heterogeneous thin film, when using scalable high-throughput processes. A unique manufacturing method called slot die printing or extrusion on-demand will be used for this experimental study. The investigation consists of three thrusts: Thrust 1 Thin Film Formation, Thrust 2, Interfacial Phenomena and Thin Film Stability, and Thrust 3, Thin Film Characterization and Analysis, to gain a basic understanding of the interfacial phenomena (wetting, spread, and adhesion) during solution coating onto heterogeneous surfaces, to elucidate mechanisms that impact the process-structure relationship of multilayer thin films. The work will further develop continuous roll-to-roll manufacture of complex multilayer films from solution, using a monolithic approach, thereby inherently decreasing fabrication cost and waste compared to traditional methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this study was to investigate the influence of wetting phenomena on selective deposition of liquid films using a novel slot die printing (SDP) technique. The specific goals of this work are to:

1.     Demonstrate simultaneous deposition of two coating fluids in alternating-stripe patterns;

2.     Investigate the influence of heterogeneous wetting regions of a precursor layer on the SDP process;

3.     Determine fluidic and wetting mechanisms that limit feature size in SDP;

4.     Develop an initial process model for SDP describing patterned film deposition on heterogeneous surfaces.

A major problem in the field of thin film processing is that materials are often developed and tailored to have particular characteristics, properties, and/or functionality (hence much attention is focused on solution/material synthesis), using non-scalable processes such as spin coating, which are also very wasteful. However, when scalable processes are implemented, the quality, properties and/or functionality of the resulting thin films are often changed. One cause of this is the influence of surface energy during the coating process. In this work a novel slot die coating process, which was recently awarded a US patent, was used to study the deposition of heterogeneous materials, to meet the aforementioned objectives.

It has been shown for the first time that it is feasible to coat multiple materials using a continuous and scalable process, namely slot die coating. Mixing at the liquid bridge region is a limiting phenomenon for the process. This effect can be mitigated by judicious material selection.  Investigations led to improvement over the resolution of conventional slot die coating more than an order of magnitude and provide a strong indication that even higher resolutions may be forthcoming in future investigations with the same approach. Conductive inks were coated which exhibited good electrical performance without the addition of surfactants or other chemical additives. The pattern morphology of the resulting films was found to be highly robust across a range of processing conditions and feature sizes, as low as 25 mm.  

Process models (both analytical and empirical) that govern the processing conditions to control the geometry of the coated narrow stripe patterns were developed. The empirical model addresses the role of influential liquid bridge phenomena in the feature size output of slot die coating in greater detail than provided by previous literature on the topic. The analytical models provide understanding of the mechanisms (pressure and secondary flow near the walls) that influence the geometric features of the stripes, to predict the pattern outflow from the SDP tool.

The work was broadly disseminated via two journal papers (with another two in preparation), nine keynotes, invited talks, and seminars at national and international conferences. Of note, the work was presented at NextFlex, NanoTech and a Gordon conference, which led to its utilization by researchers in parallel fields. Connections made at NextFlex led to an NSF INTREN for the senior graduate student at Novacentrix, and subsequently full-time employment after completing his doctorate. In addition, the PI won the L. E. Scriven Young Investigator Award for contributions made from this work.

Lastly, two graduate students, four undergraduate student and a high school student participated in this research study. Among the seven participants, there was broad diversity, including three underrepresented minorities and four women. One undergraduate participant won the LSAMP STEM Innovators Conference best paper award.

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2021
Modified by: Tequila Harris
